Solving a programing challenge on a small screen is finicky. It's easier on a big screen.

Sort algorithms in comparison
Each procedure has advantages and disadvantages. Often multiple algorithms are used, depending on the input data.
Your solution
The visualizations are based on examples from Mike Bostock and Tom MacWright. Without them, these interactive visualizations would not be possible. We're very thankful to them.
Exercise: Recognizing digits
This convolutional neural network uses six layers with up to 16 nodes. That's not a lot — 80 layers or more are not uncommon.
Draw a digit:
Reset
Watch as your drawing is centered, inverted and fed into the network:
Legend: The violet and green squares are weights; the black ones are node biases. Green is positive, violet is negative.
We trained this model in advance and simply loaded it in your browser.
This model has been initialized with somewhat random values in your browser and is not yet trained. It approximately has a chance of 10% to guess the correct digit—by chance.
Load the data to train it.
This model was initialized and trained in your browser. According to test data it has a {accuracy}% chance to guess the correct digit.
